prior_works.title: Differentiable Volumetric Rendering: Learning Implicit 3D Representations without 3D Supervision
prior_works.authors: Michael Niemeyer, Lars Mescheder, Michael Oechsle, Andreas Geiger
prior_works.role: Methodological backbone for single-view, analysis-by-synthesis 3D reconstruction
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established a robust differentiable rendering pipeline to optimize 3D shape from image evidence, which this paper leverages conceptually while augmenting the objective with hard physics (static equilibrium) constraints.

prior_works.title: Soft Rasterizer: A Differentiable Renderer for Image-based 3D Reasoning
prior_works.authors: Shichen Liu, Weikai Chen, Tianye Li, Hao Li
prior_works.role: Tool/framework enabling gradient-based mesh reconstruction from single images
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided practical differentiable rendering of meshes, a key ingredient for optimizing a 3D shape to match a single image; the present work extends such optimization by jointly enforcing physical compatibility.

prior_works.title: Galileo: Perceiving Physical Object Properties by Integrating Vision and Physics
prior_works.authors: Jiajun Wu, Ilker Yildirim, Joseph J. Lim, Bill Freeman, Joshua B. Tenenbaum
prior_works.role: Problem framing of inferring latent physical properties via simulation-based inference
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the analysis-by-synthesis paradigm for estimating material and physical parameters from visual input, which directly informs this paper’s decomposition of appearance into rest shape, forces, and mechanical properties linked through physics.

prior_works.title: Learning to See Physics via Visual De-animation
prior_works.role: Conceptual foundation for disentangling forces, object properties, and geometry from images
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed that static images contain cues about latent forces and dynamics; the new work operationalizes this idea by explicitly estimating external forces and materials and coupling them via static equilibrium during reconstruction.

prior_works.title: Make It Stand: Balancing Shapes for 3D Fabrication
prior_works.authors: Romain Prévost, Emily Whiting, Sylvain Lefebvre, Olga Sorkine-Hornung
prior_works.role: Theory/tool for enforcing static equilibrium as a hard constraint in shape design
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Pioneered optimization of shapes under gravity to satisfy static equilibrium; this paper imports the same hard-equilibrium principle to single-image 3D reconstruction to ensure physically stable outputs.

prior_works.title: Learning Physical Intuition of Block Towers Using Deep Learning
prior_works.authors: Adam Lerer, Sam Gross, Rob Fergus
prior_works.role: Evidence and supervision proxy for stability reasoning from images
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated that visual models can predict stability from a single image; the present work goes beyond prediction to enforce stability by embedding equilibrium constraints directly in the reconstruction objective.

prior_works.title: DiffTaichi: Differentiable Programming for Physical Simulation
prior_works.authors: Yuanming Hu, Tzu-Mao Li, Luke Anderson, Jonathan Ragan-Kelley, Frédo Durand
prior_works.role: Enabler for gradient-based optimization through physics simulators
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed how differentiable physics makes it practical to optimize material parameters and shapes; the paper follows this paradigm to jointly optimize rest-shape geometry and mechanical properties under physics constraints.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution—recovering a 3D object from a single image that is explicitly compatible with real-world physics—emerges by fusing single-view inverse graphics with hard physical constraints. Differentiable rendering methods such as DVR and Soft Rasterizer established the analysis-by-synthesis foundation for optimizing 3D geometry from image evidence, but they typically ignore forces and material behaviors, producing shapes that look correct yet fail under gravity or loads. In parallel, the Tenenbaum group’s Galileo and subsequent visual de-animation work framed vision as inference over latent physical properties, demonstrating that images reveal materials and forces when coupled with simulation; however, these efforts did not deliver full, physically robust 3D reconstructions. On the graphics and fabrication side, Make It Stand introduced optimizing shapes under a hard static equilibrium constraint to ensure stability—an idea this paper imports directly, but now into the single-view reconstruction loop. Finally, differentiable physics frameworks like DiffTaichi showed that gradients through simulators enable joint optimization of geometry and material parameters, a practical necessity for the proposed decomposition into rest-shape, mechanical properties, and external forces. By integrating these threads, the paper advances single-view 3D modeling from “visually plausible” to “physically compatible,” using static equilibrium as a hard constraint to link disentangled physical attributes and guarantee stability and desired deformation behavior under real-world forces.
